data: Plaque broken into four pieces, with irregular edges. Small fragment missing at the centre of the reattached pieces. Rear of plaque is relatively flat.
Five lines of Latin letters, roughly centred on stone

Well-formed and straight letters, with regular spaces between letters. Serifs on most letters. Use of comma-shaped interpuncts between each word. Letter heights reduce in size at the end of lines 2 and 3. Extended 'I' in line 5 (27 mm).

Bivona (1994, 184) dates this inscription, as well as,
                                and
                                to between the second-half of the second century CE and early third century CE
Found, together with ,  and  in contrada Madonna della Catena, on the property of Gallegra, in August 1907
Antoniou, 2022-07-06. On display in Museo Civico Baldassare Romano.
I.Sicily with the permission of the Assessorato Regionale dei Beni Culturali e dell’Identità Siciliana - Dipartimento dei Beni Culturali e dell’Identità Siciliana; photo J. Prag 2018-07-10

A large and well-displayed collection. It begins with three ante-rooms, in the first of which is a rich display of lithics (mainly Neolithic) from the surrounding area. A display of material from Himera (lion-head spouts from the Temple of Victory and red-figure craters being the principle pieces) and a numismatic gallery then follow before the main room which contains Hellenistic and Roman material from Termini Imerese itself. Small finds, sculpture and inscriptions predominate. The museum collection continues upstairs with non-archaeological material (and a single inscription). The courtyard of the building holds a large collection of architectural pieces and inscriptions
Via Marco Tullio Cicerone, 90018 - Termini Imerese (PA)
L'année épigraphique: revue des publications épigraphiques relatives a l'antiquité romaine.

ISic000163. Funerary inscription for Cornelia Scepsis

2Cornelia · Scepsis ·

4Auctus · coniugi ·

Dis manibus Cornelia Scepsis vixit annis circiter XXXVIII Auctus coniugi piissimae fecit

1DIS·MANIBUS·
2CORNELIA·SCEPSIS·
3VIX·AN·((Ↄ))·XXXVIII·
4AUCTUS·CONIUGI·
5PIISSIM·FEC

DISMANIBUSCORNELIASCEPSISVIXITANNISCIRCITERXXXVIIIAUCTUSCONIUGIPIISSIMAEFECIT

Facsimile Images

Apparatus criticus

  • Text from autopsy ;
  • line.2: There is no immediately clear answer as to what the sign "Ↄ", a reverse C, symbolises here; cf.ISic000146 and ISic000174; also CIL 6.15139 (Rome) for analogous use, as pointed out by Bivona (1994). Understanding Ↄ as signifying 'circiter' is one attractive interpretation.

English translation

Tuuli Ahlholm

To the Shades of the Underworld. Cornelia Scepsis; she lived about(?) 38 years. Auctus erected this for his most dutiful wife.

commentary

The husband of the deceased, Auctus, is known only by his cognomen. It is probable that Auctus is the same individual as identified ISic000161 and ISic000164, all found at the same time and in the same location, from which we can discern his name: L. Cornelius Auctus. Corneliae are common in Thermae Himeraeae, although the cognomen Scepsis is unknown in Sicily

Well-formed and straight letters, with regular spaces between letters. Serifs on most letters. Use of comma-shaped interpuncts between each word. Letter heights reduce in size at the end of lines 2 and 3. Extended 'I' in line 5 (27 mm).

Line 1 32 Line 2 23-29 Line 3 27-30 Line 4 28 Line 5 22 Interlineation line 1 to 2 Thermae Himeraeae Termini Imerese 37.98365, 13.69555 Bivona (1994, 184) dates this inscription, as well asISic000161, ISic000162and ISic000164to between the second-half of the second century CE and early third century CE Found, together with ISic000161, ISic000162 and ISic000164 in contrada Madonna della Catena, on the property of Gallegra, in August 190737.977321, 13.708270 Antoniou, 2022-07-06. Text from autopsy There is no immediately clear answer as to what the sign "Ↄ", a reverse C, symbolises here; cf.ISic000146and ISic000174; also CIL 6.15139 (Rome) for analogous use, as pointed out by Bivona (1994). Understanding Ↄ as signifying 'circiter' is one attractive interpretation.

To the Shades of the Underworld. Cornelia Scepsis; she lived about(?) 38 years. Auctus erected this for his most dutiful wife.

The husband of the deceased, Auctus, is known only by his cognomen. It is probable that Auctus is the same individual as identified ISic000161 and ISic000164, all found at the same time and in the same location, from which we can discern his name: L. Cornelius Auctus. Corneliae are common in Thermae Himeraeae, although the cognomen Scepsis is unknown in Sicily
